Project 1 - To do list - 3


Handling Form submission

Generally HTML form submit will work like when you click the submit button it will send the form data to the server side for process but in our project we dont have server side so we need to prevent the default HTML behavior from happening.

In angular it is pretty simple when you import FormsModule to the component it will automatically prevent the default behavior.

But we need to be notified when the submit is clicked on the client side for that FormsModule have given an event (ngSubmit).

  1. #new-task.component.html
  2. <form (ngSubmit)="onSubmitForm()">
  3. </form>


  1. #new-task.component.ts
  2. onSubmitForm(){
  3.  //code
  4. }


Once the submit is clicked all the data entered in the form should be emitted to the tasks component which has the array of tasks and the new task should be added in that array.

So We can create a new interface for new task with {title:string;summary:string;date:string} we can put it in existing task.model.ts (we can export multiple interface in single model file) or also can create a new model file.

So when the submit button is clicked it will emit the typed form value to the tasks component where we can catch the event in a method and add it to the existing tasks array using push method. Note: to add the tasks to the beginning use unshift operation.

this.tasks.push({}) - add to last

this.tasks.unshift({}) - add to first

At the end this.isAddingTask should be set to false to close the dialog box.

  1. #task.model.ts
  2. export interface NewTaskData{
  3.    title:string; 
  4.    summary:string; 
  5.    date:string;
  6. }


  1. #new-task.component.ts
  2. @Output() add = new EventEmitter<NewTaskData>();
  3. onSubmitForm(){
  4.  this.add.emit({
  5.    title: this.enteredTitle,
  6.    summary: this.enteredSummary,
  7.    date: this.enteredDate,
  8.  })
  9. }


  1. #tasks.component.html
  2. @if (isAddingTask) {
  3.    <app-new-task (cancel)="onCancelAddTask()" (add)="onAddTask($event)"/> //this will catch the emitted form data
  4. }


  1. #tasks.component.ts
  2. onAddTask(newTaskData: NewTaskData){
  3.  this.tasks.push({  //pushing new task to the array
  4.    id: new Date().getTime().toString(), //this is only to generate unique id for task using date and time
  5.    userId: this.userId,
  6.    title: newTaskData.title,
  7.    summary: newTaskData.summary,
  8.    dueDate: newTaskData.date
  9.  })
  10.  this.isAddingTask = false; //should be set to false to close the dialog box
  11. }


Content Projection with ng-content

Lets say we have a card that displays all the tasks and also each and every tasks we need to use common CSS for that we can add that css to styles.css but there is also another way for that.

create a new component called card in the folder shared.

  1. ng g c shared/card //shared folder will create automatically


Now I will put the css for elements in that card component and will use it as the wrapper in other components where this css should be applied. So we can get same structure and styling to all components where the card component is used as wrapper.

But there is one important thing to keep in the mind is that when we use a component to wrap the html content the content inside the wrap wont be displayed instead it is overwritten by the component

For example

  1. #card.component.html
  2. <div>...</div>


  1. #user.component.html
  2. <app-card><h1>Hello</h1></app-card>


The Hello wont be seen in ui it will be overwritten by '...' in card component.

It can be prevented by adding a <ng-content /> in wrapper component that is card component.

ng-content is an angular feature. It acts as a place holder for the markup (code in user.component.html). This mechanism is called content projection.

  1. #card.component.html
  2. <div>
  3.    <ng-content /> //this is the placeholder for markup where this card component is wrapped.
  4. </div>


  1. #user.component.html
  2. <app-card> //wrapper card component
  3.    <button [class.active]="selected" (click)="onSelectUser()"> //these below lines will replace ng-content in card component
  4.        <img [src]="imagePath" [alt]="user.name"/>
  5.        <span>{{user.name}}</span>
  6.    </button>
  7. </app-card>


Now the app-card can be added to task component also to make the same css work.

Pipes

It is the feature given by angular. It's a output transformer which transforms output in template.

For example say we want to display date in the task component in more readable form, we need to use pipe (|) offered by angular that is date pipe. We can also create our own pipes.

DatePipe is imported from '@agngular/common'

  1. #task.component.html
  2. <article>
  3.    <h2>{{task.title}}</h2>
  4.    <time>{{task.dueDate | date}}</time> #pipe used is date
  5.    <p>
  6.        {{task.summary}}
  7.    </p>
  8.    <p class="actions">
  9.        <button (click)="onCompleteTask()">Complete</button>
  10.    </p>
  11. </article>


  1. #task.component.ts
  2. import { DatePipe } from '@angular/common'; //imported
  3. @Component({
  4.  selector: 'app-task',
  5.  standalone: true,
  6.  imports: [CardComponent, DatePipe], //imported
  7.  templateUrl: './task.component.html',
  8.  styleUrl: './task.component.css'
  9. })


Before pipe

After Pipe

The DatePipe is also configurable that is we can configure in what format date should be shown. It can be done by adding ':' next to pipe name in html and adding the option.

For example to display date in 'M/d/yy h:mm a' in angular document it is mentioned to use short option.

  1. <time>{{task.dueDate | date: 'short'}}</time>


Service

Everything now works fine. But the coding part to display tasks are all written in the Task Component. In angular it is best practice to keep this component code as less as possible.

For example the new-task component is used to add the task and the task component is used to remove the task. For this kind of things we can use services.

We can create a service file manually or using cli.

  1. ng g s tasks/tasks


Services are files that manages operations and data that are needed by more than one components.

In our project all the tasks related data (array, add, remove) can be maintained in single service file and can be used by the components when needed.

  1. #tasks.service.ts
  2. import { NewTaskData } from "./task/task.model";

  4. export class TaskService{
  5.    private tasks = [ //we can make it private since it is used only in this class.
  6.        {
  7.          id: 't1',
  8.          userId: 'u1',
  9.          title: 'Master Angular',
  10.          summary:
  11.            'Learn all the basic and advanced features of Angular & how to apply them.',
  12.          dueDate: '2025-12-31',
  13.        },
  14.        {
  15.          id: 't2',
  16.          userId: 'u3',
  17.          title: 'Build first prototype',
  18.          summary: 'Build a first prototype of the online shop website',
  19.          dueDate: '2024-05-31',
  20.        },
  21.        {
  22.          id: 't3',
  23.          userId: 'u3',
  24.          title: 'Prepare issue template',
  25.          summary:
  26.            'Prepare and describe an issue template which will help with project management',
  27.          dueDate: '2024-06-15',
  28.        },
  29.    ]

  31.    getUserTasks(userId: string){
  32.        return this.tasks.filter((task) => task.userId === userId);
  33.    }

  35.    addTask(newTaskData: NewTaskData, userId:string){
  36.        this.tasks.push({
  37.            id: new Date().getTime().toString(),
  38.            userId: userId,
  39.            title: newTaskData.title,
  40.            summary: newTaskData.summary,
  41.            dueDate: newTaskData.date
  42.          })
  43.    }

  45.    removeTask(id:string){
  46.        this.tasks = this.tasks.filter((task) => task.id !== id);
  47.    }
  48. }


Dependency Injection

To use this service in the components we need to import it first.

Service is basically a class so it needs to be instantiated in the component to be used. To do that we can do like

private tasksService = new TaskService(); in the component file.

Then we can just call this.tasksService.getUserTasks(this.userId); to get tasks array from the service.

But this approach has problem. If we instantiate the class like this we need to create each instances in every component it is to be used. It is not best practice. Because this makes change made by one component to be not reflected in another component since both have 2 separate instances.

Thats why angular provided another feature called Dependency Injection. The main concept of dependency injection is we dont create a instance like done before instead we just tell angular that you need the instance so angular create it for you.

So angular can create instance for the service once that can be used everywhere.

To do that we should add constructor( ) { } to the component file so angular will execute the constructor in the component automatically when the component is instantiated (when used in some template). 

To tell angular which type of instance to be created we need to pass it as the argument to constructor.

Example - constructor(taskService: TaskService){ } //it will create instance for TaskService.

To make it usable in the file we can put like

  1. private taskService: TaskService
  2. constructor(taskService: TaskService){
  3. this.taskService = taskService;
  4. }


In angular we can also use like

  1. constructor(private taskService: TaskService){ }


this will assign the instance to taskService variable. It can be private or public its our choice.

While executing this part angular wont scan all files and get TaskService for us we need to inject it to let angular know it is injected and can be used when needed.

To do that we should use another decorator called @Injectable({ providedIn: 'root' }) in task.service.ts

By using this angular knows we should create an instance for the service and more importantly only one instance will be created and used among all components.

  1. #tasks.component.ts
  2. constructor(private taskService: TaskService){} //instantiated the TaskService class

  4. get selectedUserTasks(){
  5.  return this.taskService.getUserTasks(this.userId); //used the instance to call a method in TaskService
  6. }


  1. #tasks.service.ts
  2. import { Injectable } from "@angular/core"; //import injectable
  3. @Injectable({providedIn:'root'}) //decorator to let angular know this service is injectable in root level
  4. export class TaskService{ }


There is also another method to get instance of the service in component other that constructor it is inject( ).

Example - private taskService = inject(TaskService); //inject need to be imported in component.

It wont instantiate the TaskService in the component it will just inject the TaskService token to the component.

So now lets restructure the add task code based on service.

  1. #new-task.component.ts
  2. export class NewTaskComponent {
  3. @Input({required:true}) userId!:string; //we need new input to be passed while adding the task
  4. @Output() close = new EventEmitter<void>();
  5. enteredTitle ='';
  6. enteredSummary = '';
  7. enteredDate = ''
  8. private taskService = inject(TaskService); //getting instance of the service

  10. onCancelTask(){
  11.  this.close.emit();
  12. }

  14. onSubmitForm(){
  15.  this.taskService.addTask({ //addTask method from service is called and requried argument is passed
  16.    title: this.enteredTitle,
  17.    summary: this.enteredSummary,
  18.    date: this.enteredDate
  19.  }, this.userId);
  20.  this.close.emit(); //to close the dialog box
  21. }
  22. }


  1. #tasks.component.html
  2. @if (isAddingTask) {
  3.    <app-new-task [userId]="userId" (close)="onCloseAddTask()"/> //input is passed
  4. }


Now lets do complete task with the service

  1. #task.component.ts
  2.  private taskService = inject(TaskService);

  4.  onCompleteTask(){
  5.    this.taskService.removeTask(this.task.id); //method in service
  6.  }


We need to remove unwanted code from tasks.component.html and tasks.component.ts

Data Storage On client Side

Each time when the app is reloaded the added tasks are gone to prevent that lets see data storage on client side. Later we will see server side and database storage.

We use javascript localstorage for that.

Each time when app is loaded we need data from the local storage to display tasks and when add or remove operation done it should change accordingly.

Now we have learned all the angular essentials like components, service, model, injector, decorator, etc.
